11:04 am
PM

Also wanted to draw attention to this terrific post from Josh Brown

PM

http://thereformed...6/02/25/abundance/

PM

There’s too much of everything and it’s not good for anyone. It’s hurting everyone. Paradoxically, abundance is now the enemy. This sets us apart from virtually every other society throughout history.
You can blame the Federal Reserve’s loose money policies if you’d like. There is over-investment in every industry. It’s killing confidence. Nothing is worth what it used to be. We haven’t adjusted to this reality yet.
Unlimited music, nine dollars a month.
Unlimited movies and TV shows, thirteen dollars a month.
Unlimited news and journalism, zero dollars a month.

11:05 am
PM

Facebook is free. Twitter is free. Snapchat is free. Instagram is free. Youtube is free. Video game apps are free. Texting is free. Sexting is free. Skyping is free. Chatting is free. Why would you spend money on anything? Where do you think people spend their time now? Endless entertainment and content, for almost nothing.
Oil costs almost nothing too. We have so much there’s no where to even store it. Natural gas supplies are overflowing, they’re burning it off at the wellhead. Coal demand is going extinct. Copper prices, iron ore prices – it’s going bidless. No one wants it, they keep producing more regardless. Why? “I don’t know, it’s what we do.”

PM

It's a very funny post -- and very true

PM

So have a moody pic of Josh

BE

FY figs as expected/guided with EPS 2% above our forecast and at the top of the Jan guidance range. Final dividend held as expected/guided. The new £849m impairment is unsurprising given well known issues. Debt is higher given working capital, $ debt and tax on exits. We are not bulls, but shares still look interesting given the post 9M capitulation/downgrades and FY update ‘new plan’. Valuation: CY16E adj EV/EBITDA c.10x and P/E c.15x with dividend ‘affordable’ and yielding 6.8%.

11:12 am
BE

Forecasts: U/R, but limited changes expected to our FY15/16E adj FD EPS of 68.7p/53.6p (FactSet consensus 69p/55p). We are already marked-to-market.
Guidance/outlook: Previous (Jan) comment reiterated with US college enrolments flat, smaller school adoption market/K-12 and open territories, plus previous testing losses. Core is still tough in the UK and Growth is still seeing S Africa stress, with China and Brazil also under pressure. FY16E EBIT guidance range is unchanged vs Jan, at £580m to £620m (vs our £600m) and EPS 50-55p (INVe 53.6p). FY16E exceptional costs confirmed at £320m. Target cost savings plus cyclical recovery imply a punchy target £800m EBIT in FY18E vs our £766m.
FY15E sales £4468m (-2%) with LFL -2% as f/c and 9M, so no new step down. Adj EBIT £723m (flat) vs f/c £720m, so slightly better, with margin 16.2% (FY14 14.8%) vs f/c 14.6%. FD EPS 70.3p (+5%) vs f/c 68.7p - top end of guidance of 69-70p.
There is a new impairment charge of £849m on Growth and US assets – unsurprising given recent pressures and as speculated in the press.
DPS 52p (+2%) as f/c and guidance, but net debt is £654m vs f/c £248m, so worse than we expected – mostly relating to working capital, $ debt and tax on disposals (gross proceeds £1.4bn as f/c).
By region: N America -1% as f/c and 9M, with margin better at 16.3% (15.6%) vs f/c 15%, Core LFL –5% as f/c and 9M, with margin 13.6% (13.2%) vs f/c 13.9% and Growth LFL –1% as f/c, with loss £12m vs f/c profit £26m, so not great. Random House was above forecast at £90m (£69m) vs f/c £78m.

PM

Pearson (SELL, TP 450p) - Cashflow collapse
(PSON LN) Two key points from the FY results (Pearson had effectively provided the market with its FY15 EPS and FY16 guidance, as well as details of its restructuring plan, in the January trading update so there are no surprises here)

BE

Heh. I like David. He sticks to his guns.

11:13 am
PM

(1) the company has taken a £849m impairment charge related to its assets stating "management's expectations of future returns were revised down in the course of 2015%" - most of the charges related to the Growth markets (£530m, presumably Brazil / S Africa-related) and £282m to North America. Such a significant impairment implicity undermines management's claims that its problems are predominately cyclical/policy and that, longer-term, the growth story is intact and...

(2) Cashflow conversion has crashed from 90% in 2014 to 60% in 2015, which it is blaming on a variety of factors such as higher education returns in the UK, working capital etc. As a result, operating cash flow was £518m vs our £673m estimate so net debt was much higher than expected at £654m vs our £311m estimate.

This collapse will again raise concerns over their ability to sustain their guidance of a flat dividend - worth 2016 likely to be another poor year for cashflow given the restructuring charges.

BE

Overall, the shares have performed strongly (+20% over the last five weeks). But our view is still, as per our upgrade note on 21 January 2016, New restructuring programme supports a realistic return to growth and current dividend, that the latest restructuring offers a credible growth plan, that concerns over the structural headwinds lose sight of the 15y digital transition that has already taken place and the 63% of revs already from digital/services, and
the 25% EPS downgrades in the period actually stemming from EPS dilutive divestments and cyclical reasons. On a 14.6x PE for 16e and offering a 7.1% FCF yield with a c.7% DPS yield, we regard the valuation as attractive and Pearson remains one of our high-conviction Buy ratings in the sector.

BE

Restructuring plan to deliver in, what, 2019? While your main market's both in structural decline and a political football?

BE

Sure, whatever.

11:21 am
PM

In light of yesterday’s exuberant response to LLOY’s special dividend announcement, we expect the focus will be on RBS’ guidance that dividends will be resumed “later than 1Q 2017” with the goal of paying out surplus capital above a 13% CET1 ratio (at 15.5% as at end-2015), rather than the headline £2bn loss (adjusted operating profit of £4.4bn), largely as expected.

We think this focus is justified; RBS continues to execute its restructuring well, and thanks in particular to the disposal of its remaining stake in Citizens, it can now claim the title as the strongest-capitalised of the big UK banks, with a 15.5% CET1 ratio (up 430bp yoy) and a leverage ratio of 5.6% (up 140bp yoy). The disposals of International Private Banking in 2016 and Williams & Glyn in 2017 (or earlier, if it is a trade sale) will add to this. To address Deutsche Bank-type concerns, slide 41 in the presentation shows that even after dividends, there would be £2.2bn in CET1 headroom above a fully phased-in MDA (maximum distributable amount) in 2019.

PM

This capital headroom gives welcome strategic flexibility – we expect that RBS would be eager to clear the remaining “Old RBS” charges like US RMBS in 2016, so that the gap between statutory and adjusted profits is minimised by the time dividends are resumed. By division, UK Personal & Business Banking operating profit of £1.0bn was down 9% yoy, but ROE remained robust at 11.7% (adjusted ROE 26.2%); Ulster Bank ROE was 10.6%; Commercial Banking ROE was 9.8%; and Private Banking adjusted ROE was 4.9% - i.e. with the exception of continued weakness in Private Banking, decent profitability. Adjusted ROE for the total franchises was 11.2%. With restructuring and performance improvement programmes still ongoing, we see scope for improvement in all these divisions.

Tangible NAVPS stood at 352p as at end-2015, putting RBS on 0.69x price/tangible book. For a bank with a 15.5% CET1 ratio, prospects for further improvement in ROE, and big dividends in 2017, this is a low valuation. Maintain Buy.

PM

Think CS also a buyer, but can't find this morning's note

11:22 am

They had a big tome out earlier in the weak

PM

Banks generally a tactical buy -- but not a strategic investment

PM

Andrew Garthwaite

11:23 am
PM

We think the banks sell-off is overdone: Tactically, the following factors are
supportive: i) banks have sold off on concerns over developed market growth,
but now the gap between their performance and PMI new orders is close to a
post-crisis high; ii) banks' credit has lagged the sell-off in bank shares,
suggesting this has not been about credit crisis concerns; iii) banks are the most
leveraged sector to high-yield spreads, which are pricing in a 70% chance of a
recession; iv) banks' performance remains correlated to the oil price (because
of exposure to the energy sector and the correlation of oil with bond yields), and
we think the oil price has troughed; v) sector risk appetite remains very
depressed (and banks are the most correlated sector to this).
Valuations are also supportive: European banks are pricing in a 50% chance
of a crisis/economic recession, which we consider too high (with European
banks trading at a 20-year low relative to US banks).

PM

The key is profits: On this score, we see some hope, as: i) NIMs have held up
well in those countries which were the earliest in adopting negative deposit
rates; ii) France, the Netherlands and Italy still have a household deposit rate
above 1%; iii) our proxies on European provisioning (credit spreads,
employment growth and real estate prices) are not consistent with a rise in
provisions; iv) loan growth is recovering (up 1.9% to households and 0.4% to
corporates); and iv) the cost-cutting potential at European banks may have
been underestimated.

PM

However, we do not currently view the European banks sector as an
attractive long-term investment, despite our positive short-term stance:
Global debt to GDP is at an all-time high (and banks are directly and indirectly
affected by the leverage cycle), banks offer an asymmetric return profile (with
betas into market rallies lower than in sell-offs), their leverage is still high (22x in
Europe) and there is significant regulatory, tax, litigation risk and pressure on
fee income. Political risks in Europe remain high, posing a threat to banks.

11:24 am
PM

One more block

PM

Stock calls: Our European banks team's top picks are Erste, Danske and
Intesa. From a top-down perspective, we would focus on banks with high fee
income, good cost control and attractive valuations (Intesa, Danske and Lloyds
screen well on Credit Suisse HOLT®
). We would also highlight: GEM-exposed
banks; UK banks, given they have the best combination of a concentrated
market structure, the ability to reprice assets and positive deposit rates; and
French banks, which have the highest discount rate on HOLT outside of Asia.
We prefer European to US banks but would recommend a tactical overweight of
US banks at this stage (e.g. JPM and Citi). We maintain our long-standing
underweight of investment banks.

PM

Sports Direct shares have fallen greater than 40% this year and have de-rated -30% to the UK General Retail sector in the last six months. It seems the concerns around the stock focus on: i) slowdown in UK trading; ii) ongoing problems with the Austrian acquisition; and iii) corporate governance and public relations missteps. We think fears are overdone and remain constructive on the stock. Buy, TP 540p

BE

Euros should drive sales short term, acquisition strategy intact — We think the European football championships will add almost +2% to group LFL in FY17e, which, combined with consolidation of Heaton’s acquisition, will drive +11% sales growth. Although problems in Austria persist, the rest of Europe is profitable and the fairly unique nature of the Austrian market limits read-across for further European expansion, in our view. Online is a positive driver of earnings.

11:35 am
BE

FY17e PBT cut 15% — We cut our FY17e PBT forecast 15% to £280m (EPS 35.1p, -3.6% yoy) on the headwind created by the c.17% appreciation of US$ against GBP in the last 3 months. This reflects SPD buying at 1.40 USD/GBP vs a hedged rate of 1.63 in FY16.

BE

The Buyout support

potential take private transaction — At c.10x FY18e PE and 6.3x EV/EBIT the shares are trading at a c.30% discount to UK General Retail. We think this reflects a lack of earnings growth and a structurally challenged business model. Mike Ashley, whom we consider a key asset for the company, would only need to gear up the business to 3.4x net/debt EBITDA to buy out remaining shareholders at a 40% premium to current levels (542p per share).

BE

Buy rating, target price 540p (from 640p)

We think the current share price provides an attractive entry point for a business with a proven, if somewhat volatile, track record. We base our new 540p target price on Sports Direct trading at a FY18e EV/EBIT of 9x. This is a c.30% discount to its average 5-year EV/EBIT valuation and a 10% discount to the current sector FY18e EV/EBIT.

BE

Using a healthy 40% premium to the current share price indicates that Mike Ashley would only need to gear the company up to 3.4x net debt/EBITDA to buy back the publicly owned stake (assuming the JD Sports stake was sold in the process, see below). We would not expect this to be demanding or particularly onerous, given a c.5% interest rate would result in £62m of interest cost and over a 5 year period the payback would be c.£300m a year, which we forecast will be more than covered by FCF from FY18e, even given the higher interest cost. At this level of gearing, Fixed charge cover would still be c.2x so not particularly threatening.

Using a stretched net debt / EBITDA multiple of 6x would suggest a buyout is possible up to 640p a share without the need for any third party money.

Sports Direct holds a number of stakes and CFDs referencing interest in a number of other companies. Due to lack of detail we have only assumed that the stake in JD Sports is liquid enough to be sold at the current value but depending on the contracts Sports Direct may be holding a further £300m in value that can be sold to finance a buyout.

BE

How does that work then? Sports Direct sells its stakes in other businesses to finance a buyout of itself? Might other shareholders be a tad uncool about that?

@R7039275 was asking about Anglo. If you can hang on a moment I'll get the latest short position from Markit.

Anglo American PLC (AAL:LSE): Last: 439.40, up 17.25 (+4.09%), High: 445.00, Low: 425.40, Volume: 5.20m
BE

In the meantime, though, there's a Canaccord downgrade to sell.

11:45 am
BE

There's also the vaguest of speculation that Anglo might be a Chinese bid target ... but, seriously, treat that one as the lowest kind of RAW.

BE

Here's Canaccord. Sell into strength, basically.

BE

Anglo American reported underlying EBITDA of US$4,854M, down 38% from US
$7,832M, and underlying earnings were US$827M, down 63% from US$2,217M in
2014. Underlying eps was also off 63%, at 64c vs 173c in 2014. Net debt at year end
was US$12.9bn compared with guidance of US$13.0-13.5bn. The company said that
it is free cashflow positive at current commodity prices, and anticipates an additional
US$1.9bn EBIT benefit from additional cost and productivity gains in 2016. Anglo is
targeting US$3-4bn of asset disposals this year, and pro forma net debt of US$10bn by
year-end. Forecast capital expenditure for 2016 has been reduced by only US$200M
relative to December guidance levels (to US$3.0bn), while 2017 capex, at US$2.5bn, is
in line with December guidance.

11:45 am
BE

Anglo American has now provided the detail on a more aggressive plan than we or the
market anticipated. The company will focus on diamonds, Platinum Group Metals and
copper. All other assets will be managed for cash generation or disposal. This potentially
adds all coal, iron ore and nickel assets to the "For Sale" list which already included the
Niobium and Phosphate businesses, and selective assets in coal and platinum. The
company hopes to deliver US$3-4bn of asset sales this year, and US$5-6bn in total.
If fully implemented, the asset portfolio would shrink from 55 assets in 2014 to 45 in
2015, and eventually just 16 core assets.

BE

Following our review of the 2015 results, we have revised our estimates, primarily to
reflect a slightly higher cost profile than we had been forecasting at most assets. The
forecasts are based upon the current business, so clearly as the disposal programme
proceeds, there could be some material changes to estimates. We now forecast 2016
underlying EBITDA of US$3,770M (previously US$4,252M), underlying earnings of
US$317M (was US$461M) and eps of 25c (from 36c). The company has already
announced that no dividend would be paid for 2016.

BE

The revised restructuring plan is bold, but high risk. The company will be seen as
a forced seller and a price-taker by potential asset acquirers. Anglo will need to
take care with its restructuring, particularly in South Africa, where it plans to exit a
substantial asset base, but retain diamond and platinum interests. Our 350p target
price (unchanged), based on NPV, rolling 12-month earnings vs the market and EV/
EBITDA, includes a 25% discount for implementation risk. Even if the plan can be
successfully executed, with diamonds and platinum, Anglo's residual portfolio will be a
later cycle, more consumer-driven portfolio and earnings may recover later than at its
more diversified peers. Given these factors, and the fact that the share price has almost
doubled since its January lows, we downgrade our recommendation from Hold to SELL.

In terms of sellside, there's a Nomura upgrade of Burberry that seems to be doing the trick.

Burberry Group PLC (BRBY:LSE): Last: 1,234, up 54 (+4.58%), High: 1,240, Low: 1,196, Volume: 946.19k
11:55 am
BE

Since Burberry announced a review of the global market, its initiatives,
efficiency programmes, productivity and capital allocation, expectations have
risen in anticipation of change. In recent years, LFL sales have been rising
strongly, but with surprisingly flat margins. As the macroeconomic climate
becomes more challenging, we assess key areas for change at Burberry.

BE

This is Christopher Walker, who was at Lehman Brothers until D-day I think.

BE

CEO for the day; five areas of focus
• Productivity – A long-standing issue for the group is low sales densities.
Expect a focus on store location, size, product positioning and service.
• Conversion – A focus on VIP/regular customers may be more effective
than attempting to attract new customers.
• Product – Our product analysis suggests range overlap. Consolidating the
sub-brands should drive better availability, an improved shopping
experience and a more coherent product architecture.
• Costs – Committed to a cost review, we expect GBP 10m of savings in
FY17, but look at scenarios to achieve 18% and 20% margins by 2020.
• Capital allocation & share buy-back – Stricter hurdle rates and cash
payback accountability. Capex lower and strong FCF generation (5.8%
FY16/17 yield) supportive. We forecast a three-year GBP 450m buy-back
(GBP 150m pa), which could be 9% accretive to FY20E EPS, but keeps
adjusted leverage ratios under control.

11:56 am
BE

Change would be a positive; upgrading to Buy in anticipation
We expect this review to be thorough, given CEO Christopher Bailey will have
been at the helm two years in May. A change of the group’s approach would
be a positive to the market. Despite a recent rebound in the stock, we see
potential for a greater valuation if Burberry can successfully drive productivity
measures, while being more disciplined on cost and capital allocation. We
caution on a tough trading environment and potential costs of implementing
initiatives, but we see a favourable forex environment and initial benefits of
cost initiatives offsetting in FY17. Burberry’s valuation appears attractive
despite the lack of short-term growth. We upgrade the stock to Buy with a
1,500p target price. We expect FY results on 18 May to be a key catalyst.
